form.introduction: In some languages verbal negation is an auxiliary element, while in others it is simply a verbal affix. English has both the negative auxiliary not, which is an independent word that must always follow another auxiliary, and the contraction form -n’t, which is written as a suffix on the auxiliary. Examples are given for English negative transitive single-clause sentences.

EnglishExample.exItem: The boy did not hit the ball.
The boy didn’t hit the ball.
The boy will not hit the ball.
The boy won’t hit the ball.
The boy might not have hit the ball.

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have a way to express negation on either an auxiliary or the verb?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, negation may be expressed in the following ways
